      static double rangeScale(double amin, double amax, double bmin, double bmax, double b)
      Scales B by an external range change so that

      BMIN < B < BMAX
      AMIN < RESULT < AMAX

      So Given rangeScale(0, 20, 0, 10, 5) -> 10
      0 < 5 < 10
      0 < ? < 20

      would return 10

    • Method Detail

      • rangeScale

        public static double rangeScale(double amin,
                                double amax,
                                double bmin,
                                double bmax,
                                double b)
        Scales B by an external range change so that

        BMIN < B < BMAX
        AMIN < RESULT < AMAX

        So Given rangeScale(0, 20, 0, 10, 5) -> 10
        0 < 5 < 10
        0 < ? < 20

        would return 10
        Parameters:
        amin - the resulting minimum
        amax - the resulting maximum
        bmin - the initial minimum
        bmax - the initial maximum
        b - the initial value
        Returns:
        the resulting value

      • lerpInverse

        public static double lerpInverse(double from,
                                 double to,
                                 double at)
        Get the percent (inverse lerp) from "from" to "to" where "at". If from = 0 and to = 100 and at = 25 then it would return 0.25
        Parameters:
        from - the from
        to - the to
        at - the at
        Returns:
        the percent

      • lerp

        public static double lerp(double a,
                          double b,
                          double f)
        Linear interpolation from a to b where f is the percent across
        Parameters:
        a - the first pos (0)
        b - the second pos (1)
        f - the percent
        Returns:
        the value

        Bilinear interpolation
        Parameters:

        b - the second point (1, 0)
        c - the third point (0, 1)
        d - the fourth point (1, 1)
        tx - the x
        ty - the y
        Returns:
        the bilerped value

        b - the second point (1, 0, 0)

        f - the sixth point (1, 1, 0)
        g - the seventh point (0, 1, 1)
        h - the eighth point (1, 1, 1)
        x - the x
        y - the y
        z - the z

        the trilerped value

      • evaluate

        public static double evaluate(java.lang.String expression,
                              java.lang.Double... args)
                       throws javax.script.ScriptException,
                              java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
        Evaluates an expression using javascript engine and returns the double result. This can take variable parameters, so you need to define them. Parameters are defined as $[0-9]. For example evaluate("4$0/$1", 1, 2); This makes the expression (4x1)/2 == 2. Keep note that you must use 0-9, you cannot skip, or start at a number other than 0.
        Parameters:
        expression - the expression with variables
        args - the arguments/variables
        Returns:
        the resulting double value
        Throws:
        javax.script.ScriptException - ... gg
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - learn to count

      • evaluate

        public static double evaluate(java.lang.String expression)
                       throws javax.script.ScriptException
        Evaluates an expression using javascript engine and returns the double
        Parameters:
        expression - the mathimatical expression
        Returns:
        the double result
        Throws:
        javax.script.ScriptException - ... gg
